a.g: The revelation of the Qur'an is from Allah, the Exalted in Might, the Wise.
Indeed, We have sent down to you the Book, [O Muhammad], in truth. So worship Allah, [being] sincere to Him in religion.

Unquestionably, for Allah is the pure religion. And those who take protectors besides Him [say], "We only worship them that they may bring us nearer to Allah in position." Indeed, Allah will judge between them concerning that over which they differ. Indeed, Allah does not guide he who is a liar and [confirmed] disbeliever.

For the idol-worshippers said: 'We do not worship them except to bring us closer to Allah in nearness (Zulfa).' So they were entering into the beginnings of the doors of Monotheism (Tawhid) with a weak entry, and the intermediate ones are the majority. Among them are those whose insight (Basirah) opens in some states, so the realities of Monotheism (Tawhid) appear to him, but like a fleeting lightning bolt, it does not remain firm. And among them are those to whom that appears and remains for a time, but it does not endure, and endurance in it is rare: For every one there are movements toward the heights of elevation, but rare among men is steadfastness.

a.g: If Allah had intended to take a son, He could have chosen from what He creates whatever He willed. Exalted is He; He is Allah, the One, the Prevailing.

He created the heavens and earth in truth. He wraps the night over the day and wraps the day over the night and has subjected the sun and the moon, each running [its course] for a specified term. Unquestionably, He is the Exalted in Might, the Perpetual Forgiver.

He created you from one soul. Then He made from it its mate, and He produced for you from the grazing livestock eight mates. He creates you in the wombs of your mothers, creation after creation, within three darknesses. That is Allah, your Lord; to Him belongs dominion. There is no deity except Him, so how are you averted?

If you disbelieve - indeed, Allah is Free from need of you. And He does not approve for His servants disbelief. And if you are grateful, He approves it for you; and no bearer of burdens will bear the burden of another. Then to your Lord is your return, and He will inform you about what you used to do. Indeed, He is Knowing of that within the breasts.

ğŸ“– Vol 3: Condemnation of Self-Delusion
If you say: Where is the error in the statement of the sinners and the wicked that Allah is generous and we hope for His mercy and forgiveness, and He has said 'I am as My servant thinks of Me, so let him think good of Me'? This is nothing but speech that is correct and acceptable in appearance to the hearts. Know that Satan does not misguide the human except with speech that is acceptable in appearance but rejected in its inner meaning, and were it not for the goodness of its appearance, the hearts would not be deceived by it. But the Prophet (peace be upon him) uncovered that by saying: 'The intelligent one is he who holds his Soul (Nafs) accountable and works for what is after death, and the fool is he who follows his Soul's (Nafs) desires and wishes upon Allah.' This is wishing upon Allah, the Exalted, but Satan changed its name and called it: hope, until he deceived the ignorant with it. And Allah has explained hope by saying: 'Indeed, those who have believed and those who have emigrated and striven in the path of Allah - those hope for the mercy of Allah.' Meaning that hope is more fitting for them, and this is because He mentioned that: 'If you disbelieve - indeed, Allah is Free from need of you. And He does not approve for His servants disbelief. And if you are grateful, He approves it for you. And no bearer of burdens will bear the burden of another. Then to your Lord is your return, and He will inform you about what you used to do. Indeed, He is Knowing of that within the chests.'

Sins (al-Ma'asi) are hated, yet with that hatred they are willed, and acts of obedience (al-Ta'at) are willed and intended to be willed, loved, and pleasing. As for disbelief (al-Kufr) and evil (al-Sharr), we do not say they are pleasing and loved, but they are willed. And Allah the Exalted has said: 'And He does not approve for His servants disbelief (al-Kufr).' So how can annihilation, in relation to Allah's love and hatred, be like permanence? For He the Exalted says: 'I have not hesitated in anything as I hesitate in taking the soul (al-Ruh) of My believing servant (al-'Abd al-Muslim); he hates death, and I hate to harm him, but death is inevitable for him.' [15] His statement 'death is inevitable for him' points to the precedence of the Will and the decree mentioned in His saying: 'We have decreed death among you' and in His saying: 'The Creator of death and life.' And there is no contradiction between His saying: 'We have decreed death among you' and His saying: 'and I hate to harm him,' but clarifying the truth in this requires verifying the meaning of the Will (al-Iradah), love (al-Mahabbah), and hatred (al-Karahiyyah), and explaining their realities.

Its evidences from the Quran are His saying, the Mighty and Majestic: 'Allah bears witness that there is no deity except Him, and [so do] the angels and those of knowledge - [that He is] maintaining [creation] in justice' (Al Imran 3:18). So observe how He, the Exalted, began with Himself, then mentioned the angels, and thirdly mentioned the people of knowledge - and what honor, excellence, clarity, and nobility is greater than this! And Allah, the Exalted, says: 'Allah will raise those who have believed among you and those who were given knowledge by degrees' (Al-Mujadilah: 11). Ibn Abbas, may Allah be pleased with them both, said: 'For the scholars are degrees above the believers by seven hundred degrees, the distance between each two degrees being a journey of five hundred years.' And the Mighty and Majestic says: 'Say, "Are those who know equal to those who do not know?"' And He, the Exalted, says: 'Only those fear Allah from among His servants who are knowledgeable.' And He, the Exalted, says: 'Say, "Sufficient is Allah as Witness between me and you, and [by] whoever has knowledge of the Scripture."' And He, the Exalted, says: 'Said one who had knowledge from the Scripture, "I will bring it to you."' indicating that he was able through the power of knowledge. And the Mighty and Majestic says: 'But those who were given knowledge said, "Woe to you! The reward of Allah is better for he who believes and does righteousness."' clarifying that the greatness of the Hereafter's value is known through knowledge. And He, the Exalted, says: 'And these examples We present to the people, but none will understand them except those of knowledge.' And He, the Exalted, says: 'And if they had referred it back to the Messenger or to those of authority among them, then the ones who [can] draw correct conclusions from it would have known about it.' He referred its ruling in matters to their deduction and equated their rank with the rank of the prophets in uncovering Allah's ruling. And it is said regarding His saying, the Exalted: 'O children of Adam, We have bestowed upon you clothing to conceal your private parts' meaning knowledge, 'and adornment' meaning certainty (Yaqin), 'but the clothing of righteousness' meaning modesty (Haya). And the Mighty and Majestic says: 'And We had certainly brought them a Book which We detailed by knowledge.' And He, the Exalted, says: 'So We will surely relate [their deeds] to them with knowledge.' And the Mighty and Majestic says: 'Rather, it is distinct verses [preserved] in the breasts of those who have been given knowledge.' And He, the Exalted, says: 'He created man, [and] taught him eloquence.' And He mentioned that in the context of favor.

ğŸ“– Vol 4: Patience and Gratitude
Then on the Day of Resurrection, the people of deeds will be brought and their deeds will be weighed in the balance - the people of prayer, fasting, charity, and pilgrimage. Then the people of affliction will be brought, and no balance will be set up for them, nor will any record be spread out for them. Their reward will be poured upon them as the affliction was poured upon them. And Umar ibn Abd al-Aziz, may Allah have mercy on him, said in his sermon: 'Allah has not bestowed a blessing upon a servant then withdrawn it from him and compensated him with Patience (Sabr) except that what He compensated him with was better than what He withdrew from him.' ğŸ“– Vol 4: Patience and Gratitude
We say: This station in explanation rejects investigation and detail, and its requirement is looking at the apparent understood from the sources of the Sharia, and that necessitates preferring Patience (Sabr). For Gratitude (Shukr), even though many reports have come regarding its virtue, when what has come regarding the virtue of Patience is added to it, the virtues of Patience are more numerous. Rather, there are explicit expressions in preference, like his saying ï­¬: 'From the best of what you have been given is Certainty (Yaqeen) and the resolve of Patience (Sabr)' [113]. And in the report: 'The most grateful of the people of the earth will be brought, and Allah will reward him the reward of the grateful ones, and the most patient of the people of the earth will be brought and it will be said to him: Are you not satisfied that We reward you as We rewarded this grateful one? He says: Yes, O Lord. Then Allah the Exalted says: No, I bestowed favor upon him so he was grateful, and I tested you so you were patient, I will multiply for you the reward for it, and he is given multiples of the reward of the grateful ones' [114]. And Allah the Exalted has said: 'Indeed, the Patient ones (Sabirun) are given their reward without account' (Quran 39:10). As for his saying: 'The eating grateful one is in the position of the fasting patient one' [115], it is evidence that the virtue is in Patience, for he mentioned that in the context of exaggeration to raise the degree of Gratitude, so he attached it to Patience, so this was the utmost of its degree. And were it not that it was understood from the Sharia the high degree of Patience, attaching Gratitude to it would not have been an exaggeration in Gratitude. And it is like his saying ï­¬: 'Friday is the Hajj of the poor, and the struggle (Jihad) of the woman is good companionship' [116], and like his saying ï­¬: 'The drinker of wine is like a worshipper of idols' [117]. And always, the thing being compared to should be of higher rank. Likewise, his saying ï­¬: 'Patience (Sabr) is half of Faith (Iman)' does not indicate that Gratitude is equal to it, and it is like his saying ï­¬: 'Fasting (Sawm) is half of Patience (Sabr)'. For everything that divides into two parts, one of them is called a half even if there is disparity between them, just as it is said: Faith (Iman) is Knowledge (Ilm) and Action (Amal), so Action is half of Faith, and that does not indicate that Action equals Knowledge. And in the report from the Prophet ï­¬: 'The last of the Prophets to enter Paradise is Sulaiman son of Dawud, peace be upon them, because of his kingdom, and the last of my companions to enter Paradise is Abd al-Rahman ibn Awf because of his wealth' [118]. And in another report: 'Sulaiman will enter after the Prophets by forty autumns' [119]. And in the report: 'All the gates of Paradise have two leaves except the gate of Patience (Sabr), for it has one leaf, and the first to enter it are the people of affliction, with Ayyub at their forefront.'

And it is said regarding His saying, the Exalted: 'So no soul knows what has been hidden for them of comfort for the eyes as a reward for what they used to do' (Quran 32:17), it is said their deed was fasting because He said: 'Indeed, the patient ones (As-Sabirun) will be given their reward without account' (Quran 39:10). Thus, the reward for the fasting person is poured out completely and given generously, not entering under estimation and calculation, and it is worthy to be so because fasting is specifically for Him and honored in relation to Him, even though all acts of worship are for Him, just as the House (Al-Bayt) is honored in relation to Himself and all the earth is His, for two reasons: First, fasting is restraint and abandonment, and it is in itself a secret with no visible action, and all acts of obedience are witnessed and seen by creation, but fasting is not seen except by Allah, the Exalted, for it is an action in the inner self (Al-Batin) with pure patience (As-Sabr). Second, it is a subduing of the enemy of Allah, the Exalted, for the means of Satan, may Allah curse him, are the desires (Ash-Shahawat), and the desires are strengthened by eating and drinking. Therefore, the Prophet (peace be upon him) said: 'Indeed, Satan flows in the son of Adam like blood, so constrict his pathways with hunger.' And therefore, the Prophet (peace be upon him) said to Aisha (may Allah be pleased with her): 'Persist in knocking on the door of Paradise.' She said: 'With what?' He said: 'With hunger.' And the virtue of hunger will come in the book on the evil of food and its treatment from the quarter of the destroyers. And among them are those who died while listening to the verses, so such states take him out from being a mere narrator in his speech. If he says, 'Indeed, I fear if I disobey my Lord the punishment of a tremendous day' (Quran 39:13) and he is not fearful, he is a mere narrator. And if he says, 'Upon You we rely and to You we turn back, and to You is the destination' (Quran 60:4) and his state is not one of reliance (Tawakkul) and turning back (Inabah), he is a mere narrator. And if he says, 'And we will be patient over what you harm us' (Quran 14:12), then let his state be patience or resolve upon it until he finds the sweetness of recitation. For if he is not with these attributes and his heart (Qalb) does not fluctuate between these states, his share of the recitation is the movement of the tongue with the explicit curse upon himself in His saying, the Exalted, 'Indeed, the curse of Allah is upon the wrongdoers' (Quran 11:18).

And the base nature (Ø§Ù„Ø·Ø¨Ø¹ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ø¦ÙŠÙ…) inclines toward following faults and turning away from good deeds, even to estimating a fault in what has no fault by lowering to the level of desire to use it as an excuse, and this is from the subtleties of Satan's stratagems. Therefore, Allah described those who repel Satan in this by His saying: 'Those who listen to speech and follow the best of it' (Quran 39:18). And the Prophet (peace be upon him) struck an example for this and said: 'The likeness of one who sits listening to wisdom then does not act except by the worst of what he hears is like a man who came to a shepherd and said to him: O shepherd, bring me a sheep from your flock. He said: Go and take the best sheep in it. So he (peace be upon him) went and took the ear of the sheepdog.' The hadith: 'The likeness of one who hears wisdom then does not carry from it except the worst of what he hears is like a man who came to a shepherd and said: O shepherd, bring me a sheep from your flock.' a.g: Then, is one who has deserved the decree of punishment [to be guided]? Then, can you save one who is in the Fire?
But those who have feared their Lord - for them are chambers, above them chambers built high, beneath which rivers flow. [This is] the promise of Allah. Allah does not fail in [His] promise.

Do you not see that Allah sends down rain from the sky and makes it flow as springs [and rivers] in the earth; then He produces thereby crops of varying colors; then they dry and you see them turned yellow; then He makes them [scattered] debris. Indeed in that is a reminder for those of understanding.

So is one whose breast Allah has expanded to [accept] Islam and he is upon a light from his Lord [like one whose heart rejects it]? Then woe to those whose hearts are hardened against the remembrance of Allah. Those are in manifest error.

And the third guidance is beyond the second, and it is the Light (Nur) that shines in the world of Prophethood (Nubuwwah) and Sainthood (Wilayah) after the perfection of spiritual struggle (Mujahadah), so one is guided by it except what cannot be guided to by the intellect (Aql) through which religious obligation (Taklif) and the possibility of learning sciences are attained, and it is the absolute inclination (Hawa), and everything else is a veil for it and preliminaries. And it is that which Allah the Exalted honored by specifying the attribution to Him, even though all is from His side, as He said: 'Say: Indeed, the guidance of Allah is the guidance' (6:71). And it is called life in His saying: 'Or one who was dead, then We gave him life and made for him a light by which he walks among the people' (6:122). And the meaning of His saying: 'So is one whose chest Allah has expanded for Islam, then he is upon a light from his Lord' (39:22). As for sound judgment (Rushd), we mean by it the divine care (Inayah Ilahiyyah) that assists the human when he turns to his objectives, so it directs him to what contains his rectification and diverts him from what contains his corruption, and that is from the inner dimension (Batin) as He said: 'And We had certainly given Abraham his sound judgment before, and We were of him knowing' (21:51). So sound judgment (Rushd) is an expression for a guidance that urges toward the direction of happiness and moves toward it. For the boy when he reaches maturity, knowledgeable about preserving wealth and ways of trade and increase, but with that he squanders and does not desire increase, he is not called sound-judging (Rashid), not due to lack of guidance but due to the deficiency of his guidance in moving his motivation. How many a person proceeds with what he knows harms him; he has been given the guidance and distinguished by it from the ignorant one who does not know that it harms him, but he has not been given sound judgment (Rushd). So sound judgment (Rushd) by this consideration is more complete than mere guidance to the aspects of actions, and it is a great blessing.

ğŸ“– Vol 4: Love, Longing, and Intimacy
Likewise, in the Heart (Qalb) there is an instinct called the Divine Light (Nur Ilahi) due to His saying, the Exalted: "Is he whose breast Allah has expanded to Islam, so he is upon a light from his Lord?" (Quran 39:22). It may be called the Intellect (Aql), it may be called the Inner Insight (Basirah Batina), and it may be called the Light of Faith and Certainty (Nur al-Iman wal-Yaqin). There is no meaning in preoccupation with names, for terminologies differ. The weak one thinks that the difference occurs in the meanings because the weak one seeks meanings from words, which is the opposite of what is obligatory. The Heart (Qalb) is distinct from other parts of the body by a quality through which it perceives meanings that are neither imagined nor sensed, such as perceiving the creation of the world or its need for an Ancient Creator, a Manager, Wise, described with divine attributes. Name that instinct Intellect (Aql) on the condition that one does not understand from the term Intellect (Aql) that by which the methods of disputation and debate are perceived, for the name Intellect (Aql) has become famous with this meaning, and for this reason some Sufis have criticized it. Otherwise, the attribute by which man differs from beasts and through which he perceives the Knowledge (Ma'rifah) of Allah, the Exalted, is the most noble of attributes and should not be criticized. This instinct was created to know with it the realities of all matters, so the requirement of its nature is Knowledge (Ma'rifah) and Science (Ilm), and that is its pleasure, just as the requirement of other instincts is their pleasure.

And likewise, mere belief without unveiling (kashf) is of much benefit in comparison to mere utterance of the tongue, but deficient in rank in comparison to the unveiling (kashf) and witnessing (mushahada) that occur through the expansion (inshirah) of the chest (sadr) and its opening up, and the illumination of the light (nur) of the Truth (al-Haqq) within it. ğŸ“– Vol 3: Wonders of the Heart
The purpose of acts of obedience and bodily deeds is all purification of the Heart (Qalb), its refinement, and its polishing. 'He has succeeded who purifies it' (Quran 91:9). The purpose of its refinement is the attainment of the lights of Faith (Iman) within it, meaning the shining of the light of Knowledge (Ma'rifah). This is what is intended by His saying, the Exalted: 'So whoever Allah wants to guide - He expands his breast to Islam. Is he whose breast Allah has expanded to Islam, so he is upon a light from his Lord?' (Quran 39:22). Yes, this manifestation and this Faith (Iman) have three levels. The first level is the Faith (Iman) of the common people, which is Faith (Iman) of pure imitation (Taqleed). The second is the Faith (Iman) of the theologians, which is mixed with a kind of reasoning, and its degree is close to the degree of the Faith (Iman) of the common people. The third is the Faith (Iman) of the Knowers (Arifin), which is witnessed by the light of Certainty (Yaqeen). We will explain these levels to you with an example: that your belief in Zayd being, for example, in the house has three degrees. The first is that one whom you have experienced as truthful, and you do not know him to lie nor suspect him in speech, informs you. Then your Heart (Qalb) finds tranquility in him and is at peace with his report by mere hearing. This Faith (Iman) is by mere imitation (Taqleed), and it is like the Faith (Iman) of the common people. a.g: Allah has sent down the best statement: a consistent Book wherein is reiteration. The skins shiver therefrom of those who fear their Lord; then their skins and their hearts relax at the remembrance of Allah. That is the guidance of Allah by which He guides whom He wills. And one whom Allah leaves astray - for him there is no guide.
Then is he who will shield with his face the worst of the punishment on the Day of Resurrection [like one secure from it]? And it will be said to the wrongdoers, "Taste what you used to earn."
Those before them denied, and punishment came upon them from where they did not perceive.
So Allah made them taste disgrace in worldly life. But the punishment of the Hereafter is greater, if they only knew.

ğŸ“– Vol 2: Etiquette of Seclusion
Therefore, whoever confines his Soul (Nafs) in the house to improve people's beliefs and statements about him, he is in present hardship in the worldly life (Al-Dunya), and the punishment of the Hereafter (Al-Akhirah) is greater, if they only knew. Therefore, seclusion is not recommended except for one who is completely absorbed in his Lord with Remembrance (Dhikr), contemplation, worship, and knowledge, such that if he mixed with people, his times would be wasted, his harms would increase, and his acts of worship would become confused for him. These are hidden dangers in choosing seclusion that should be guarded against, for they are destroyers in the guise of saviors.

ğŸ“– Vol 4: Love, Longing, and Intimacy
As for the fifth cause of love, it is suitability and resemblance because the likeness of a thing is attracted to it, and shape is more inclined to shape. Therefore, you see the child befriends the child and the adult befriends the adult, and the bird befriends its kind and shuns other kinds, and the scholar finds more companionship with the scholar than with the craftsman, and the carpenter finds more companionship with the carpenter than with the blacksmith, and the jurist finds more companionship with the jurist than with the physician, and the Sufi finds more companionship with the Sufi than with the jurist, and the knower (of God) finds more companionship with the knower than with the Sufi, and the angels find more companionship with the angels than with humans, and humans find more companionship with humans than with angels, and the jinn find more companionship with the jinn than with humans, and the animal finds more companionship with the animal than with the human, and the plant finds more companionship with the plant than with the animal, and the inanimate finds more companionship with the inanimate than with the plant. All of this is because everything inclines towards its likeness. Therefore, Allah the Exalted said: "Allah presents an example: a man owned by quarreling partners and a man belonging entirely to one man. Are they equal in comparison? Praise be to Allah. But most of them do not know." [Quran 39:29]. The quarreling ones are those who differ in demands and objectives, sharing in ownership, so each one wants to drive him to his direction, causing the servant to be in confusion and disturbance. As for the man belonging entirely, he has only one master, so he submits to him in all his affairs, and his heart is not disturbed by multiple demands. Similarly, the Heart (Qalb) if its demands multiply from worldly desires and desires of the Hereafter, and from demands of the Soul (Nafs) and demands of the Spirit (Ruh), and from demands of the senses and demands of the intellect, and from demands of the kingdom and demands of the dominion, it becomes disturbed and confused, and does not reach tranquility or stillness. But if it becomes exclusive in love for Allah the Exalted, and submits to Him in all its affairs, and surrenders to His command and prohibition, and is safe from its soul-based and satanic demands, it becomes safe and its heart becomes safe, and its soul becomes tranquil, and its states become settled. This is the meaning of His saying the Exalted: "Unquestionably, by the Remembrance (Dhikr) of Allah hearts are assured." [Quran 13:28]. The Remembrance (Dhikr) of Allah is what assures the heart and purifies it from multiple demands and quarreling partners. So love for Allah the Exalted due to suitability and resemblance is stronger than other causes, because Allah the Exalted created man in His image, as in the hadith: "Indeed, Allah created Adam in His image," so in man there is from the attributes of beauty and perfection what suits the beauty and perfection of Allah, so there is suitability between the Creator and the creation, thus the heart is attracted to love for Him, as likeness is attracted to its likeness. This love is what yields tranquility and stillness, and purifies the heart from quarreling partners.

And among them is arrogance (Istikbar) towards the truth (Haqq) and hatred of it, and eagerness for disputation (Mira') in it, to the extent that the most hated thing to the disputant is that the truth appears on the tongue of his opponent. From these two emerges exertion for its denial and rejection with his utmost effort and expending the limit of his capability in deception, cunning, and trickery to repel it, until disputation in it becomes a natural habit. So he does not hear any speech except that there arises from his nature an urge to object to it, until that overcomes his heart (Qalb) in the proofs of the Quran and the expressions of the Sharia, so he strikes some of them against others. And disputation in opposition to falsehood is cautioned against, as the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, encouraged leaving disputation with truth against falsehood. He said, peace be upon him: 'Whoever leaves disputation while he is false, Allah will build for him a house in the outskirts of Paradise; and whoever leaves disputation while he is truthful, Allah will build for him a house in the highest part of Paradise.' And Allah the Exalted has equated between one who fabricates lies against Allah and one who denies the truth, as He said: 'And who is more unjust than one who invents a lie about Allah or denies the truth when it has come to him?' (Al-Ankabut: 68). And He said: 'Then who is more unjust than one who lies about Allah and denies the truth when it has come to him? Is there not in Hell a residence for the disbelievers?' (Az-Zumar: 32).

And due to the correspondence and congruence of that, Allah the Exalted attributed actions in the Quran once to the angels and once to the servants, and attributed the very same actions another time to Himself. And He the Exalted said: "Have you considered what you sow?" He attributed it to us, then He the Exalted said: "We pour down water in abundance, then We split the earth in clefts, and We cause therein the grain to grow, and grapes." And He the Exalted said: "So We sent to her Our Spirit (Ruh), and he represented himself to her as a well-proportioned man." Then He the Exalted said: "And We breathed into her from Our Spirit (Ruh)." And the one who breathed was Gabriel, peace be upon him. And as He the Exalted said: "So when We have recited it, then follow its recitation." It is said in the interpretation: Its meaning is when Gabriel recites it to you. And He the Exalted said: "Fight them; Allah will punish them by your hands." So He attributed the killing to them and the punishment to Himself, and the punishment is the very killing. Rather, He explicitly said: "So you did not kill them, but Allah killed them." And He the Exalted said: "And you did not throw when you threw, but Allah threw." And it combines negation and affirmation apparently, but its meaning is: And you did not throw in the sense by which the Lord is a thrower, when you threw in the sense by which the servant is a thrower, for they are two different meanings.

And Dhul-Nun al-Misri said: I went out one night from the valley of Canaan, and when I ascended the valley, behold, a dark figure approaching me, and it was saying: 'And there will appear to them from Allah what they had not been reckoning (with)' and weeping. She said: 'O this one, and is there any estrangement with Allah?' He said: So I wept at her statement. She said: 'What made you weep?' I said: 'The remedy has fallen upon a wound that has festered, so it hastens in its healing.' She said: 'If you are truthful, then why did you weep?' I said: 'May Allah have mercy on you, and the truthful one does not weep.' She said: 'No.' I said: 'And why is that?' She said: 'Because weeping is a relief for the Heart (Qalb).' So I fell silent, astonished at her statement.

If it happens that his spirit (Ruh) departs in this peril before he stabilizes and returns to the original faith, then he has been sealed with evil and his spirit has departed upon polytheism (Shirk) - we seek refuge in Allah from it. And regarding them, the Exalted and Majestic said: 'And there will appear to them from Allah what they had never taken into account.' It is said: these are deeds they thought were good deeds, but they are actually bad deeds. And the most subtle type of knowledge of spiritual conduct (Mu'amalah) is to stand firm against the deceptions of the Soul (Nafs) and the plots of Satan (Shaytan). This is an individual obligation (Fard 'Ayn) upon every servant, yet the creation has neglected it and occupied themselves with sciences that attract to them the whisperings (Waswas) and empower over them Satan (Shaytan), making them forget his enmity and the way to guard against him. And nothing saves from the abundance of whisperings (Waswas) except blocking the doors of thoughts, and their doors are the five senses, and their doors from within are the desires (Shahawat) and attachments of the worldly life. Seclusion in a dark house blocks the door of the senses, and detachment from family and wealth reduces the entrances of whisperings (Waswas) from the inner self (Batin). Yet, there remain inner entrances in the imaginings flowing in the Heart (Qalb). This cannot be repelled except by occupying the Heart (Qalb) with the Remembrance (Dhikr) of Allah, the Exalted. Then, indeed, it (Satan) continually pulls the Heart (Qalb), contends with it, and distracts it from the Remembrance (Dhikr) of Allah, the Exalted. So, striving against it (Mujahadah) is necessary, and this striving (Mujahadah) has no end except death, for no one is freed from Satan (Shaytan) as long as he is alive. Yes, one may become strong such that he does not yield to him and repels his harm through striving (Jihad), but he never dispenses with striving (Jihad) and defense as long as blood flows in his body. ğŸ“– Vol 4: Fear and Hope
The Second Art: The examination of verses and reports, for what has come regarding hope is beyond enumeration. As for the verses, the Exalted has said: 'Say: O My servants who have been excessive against their own souls (Nafs), do not despair of the mercy of Allah. Indeed, Allah forgives all sins. Indeed, He is the Forgiving, the Merciful.' {} And in the recitation of the Messenger of Allah ï·º: 'And He does not care, indeed He is the Forgiving, the Merciful' [12]. And the Exalted said: 'And the angels glorify with the praise of their Lord and seek forgiveness for those on earth' {}. And the Exalted informed that the Fire He prepared for His enemies, and He only frightened with it His allies, so He said: 'For them are shades from the Fire above them and shades beneath them. That is how Allah frightens His servants' {}. And the Exalted said: 'And fear the Fire which has been prepared for the disbelievers' {}. And the Exalted said: 'So I have warned you of a Fire that blazes, none will reach it except the most wretched, who denied and turned away' {}. And the Mighty and Majestic said: 'And indeed your Lord is full of forgiveness for the people despite their wrongdoing' {}. And it is said: (Indeed, the Prophet ï·º did not cease asking for his community until it was said to him: Are you not satisfied when this verse has been revealed to you: 'And indeed your Lord is full of forgiveness for the people despite their wrongdoing' {} [13]). And in the interpretation of His saying, the Exalted: 'And your Lord will give you, and you will be satisfied' {}, he said: Muhammad will not be satisfied while one of his community is in the Fire. Know that acting upon Hope (Ar-RajÄ') is higher than acting upon Fear (Al-Khawf) because the closest of servants to Allah the Exalted are those who love Him most, and Love (Al-Hubb) overcomes Hope. Consider this with two kings: one serves out of fear of his punishment, and the other out of hope for his reward. Therefore, in Hope and good assumption (Husn Az-Zann), there are incentives, especially at the time of death. Allah the Exalted said: 'Say: O My servants who have transgressed against themselves, do not despair of the Mercy of Allah. Indeed, Allah forgives all sins. Indeed, He is the Forgiving, the Merciful.' So He prohibited the root of Despair (Al-Ya's). And in the reports of Ya'qub, peace be upon him, Allah the Exalted revealed to him: 'Do you know why I separated between you and Yusuf? Because you said: I fear that the wolf will eat him while you are heedless of him. Why did you fear the wolf and not hope in Me? You looked at the heedlessness of his brothers and did not look at My preservation of him.' And the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, said: 'Let none of you die except while having a good assumption about Allah the Exalted.' And the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, said: 'Allah the Mighty and Majestic says: I am as My servant assumes of Me, so let him assume of Me what he wills.' And the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, entered upon a man while he was in the death throes and said: 'How do you find yourself?' He said: 'I find myself fearing my sins and hoping for the Mercy of my Lord.' The Prophet said: 'These two do not gather in the heart of a servant at this station except that Allah gives him what he hopes and secures him from what he fears.' And Ali, may Allah be pleased with him, said to a man whom Fear had brought to Despair due to the multitude of his sins: 'O this one, your despair from the Mercy of Allah is greater than your sins.' And Sufyan said: 'Whoever commits a sin and knows that Allah the Exalted decreed it upon him and hopes for His forgiveness, Allah forgives him his sin.' He said: 'Because Allah the Mighty and Majestic reproached a people, saying: "And that was your assumption which you assumed about your Lord that has ruined you." And Allah the Exalted said: "And you assumed an evil assumption and you were a people ruined." And the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, said: 'Indeed, Allah the Exalted says to the servant on the Day of Resurrection: What prevented you when you saw the evil from forbidding it? ğŸ“– Vol 4: Fear and Hope
Look at how He drives the creation with the whips of fear and leads them with the reins of hope to Allah the Exalted, for He first drove them with the whips of fear. When that took them beyond the limit of moderation to the excess of despair, He treated them with the medicine of hope and returned them to moderation and balance. The latter was not contradictory to the former, but He mentioned in the first what He saw as a cause for healing and confined Himself to it. When they needed treatment with hope, He mentioned the completion of the matter. So the preacher must follow the master of preachers and be gentle in using the reports of fear and hope according to the need, after observing the hidden ailments. If he does not observe that, what he corrupts with his preaching is more than what he rectifies. In the report: 'If you did not sin, Allah would create a creation that sins so He may forgive them.' And in another wording: 'He would take you away and bring a creation that sins so He may forgive them, for He is the All-Forgiving, the Most Merciful.' And in the report: 'If you did not sin, I would fear for you what is worse than sins.' It was said: 'And what is it?' He said: 'Pride.' And the Prophet (peace be upon him) said: 'By the One in Whose hand is my soul, Allah is more merciful to His believing servant than the compassionate mother to her child.' ğŸ“– Vol 4: Remembrance of Death and the Afterlife
And before the beginning of the questioning, the light of the Throne appears: 'And the earth will shine with the light of its Lord' (Quran 39:69). And every servant (Abd) became certain of the approach of the Almighty (Al-Jabbar) for questioning the servants, and each one thought that no one sees him except Him and that he is the one taken for taking and questioning, not anyone else. Then the Almighty (Al-Jabbar), glorified and exalted, says at that time: 'O Gabriel, bring the Fire.' So Gabriel comes for it and says: 'O Hell, respond to your Creator and your Sovereign.' Gabriel finds it in its rage and anger, and it did not linger after his call before it erupted, boiled, and snorted towards the creatures, and it gasped, and the creatures heard its rage and snorting, and its keepers rose up, leaping towards the creatures in anger at those who disobeyed Allah, exalted is He, and opposed His command. So imagine in your mind and present in your heart (Qalb) the state of the hearts (Qulub) of the servants, which have filled with terror and dread, so they fell prostrate on their knees and turned away fleeing: 'On the Day you will see every nation kneeling' (Quran 45:28). And some of them fell on their faces, prostrate, and the sinners and wrongdoers call out with woe and ruin, and the truthful ones call out: 'Myself, myself!' While they are like that, the people snorted its second snort, so their fear multiplied and their strengths weakened, and they thought they were being taken. Then it snorted the third time, so the creatures fell on their faces and stared with their eyes, looking from a hidden, humble corner, and at that, the hearts (Qulub) of the wrongdoers were crushed, reaching the throats, suppressing, and the minds (Aql) of the fortunate and the wretched all were bewildered. And after that, Allah, exalted is He, turned to the messengers and said: 'What did you answer?' So when they saw...

ğŸ“– Vol 3: Condemnation of Pride and Conceit
And the blameworthy character traits are interconnected, and some of them inevitably lead to others. The worst type of arrogance (Kibr) is what prevents benefiting from knowledge and accepting the truth and submitting to it, and in this context came the verses that contain condemnation of arrogance (Kibr) and the arrogant ones (Mutakabbirun). Allah the Exalted said: "And the angels will be spreading their hands" up to His saying: "and you were arrogant (Tastakbirun) towards His signs." Then He said: "Enter the gates of Hell (Jahannam), abiding therein. So wretched is the abode of the arrogant (Mutakabbirun)." Then He informed that the most severely punished people of the Fire (Nar) are those most insolent (Atiyyan) against Allah the Exalted, so He said: "Then We will surely extract from every sect those of them who were most insolent (Atiyyan) against the Most Merciful." And He the Exalted said: "So those who do not believe in the Hereafter (Akhirah) - their hearts (Qulub) are denying, and they are arrogant (Mustakbirun)." And He the Mighty and Majestic said: "Those who were oppressed will say to those who were arrogant (Istakbaru): 'If not for you, we would have been believers.'" And He the Exalted said: "Indeed, those who are arrogant (Yastakbirun) towards My worship will enter Hell (Jahannam) debased." And He the Exalted said: "I will turn away from My signs those who are arrogant (Yatakabbarun) on the earth without right." It is said in the interpretation (Tafsir): I will lift the understanding of the Quran from their hearts (Qulub), and in some interpretations (Tafasir): I will veil their hearts (Qulub) from the dominion (Malakut). And Ibn Juraij said: I will turn them away from reflecting upon them and taking admonition from them. And therefore, Jesus (Al-Masih) peace be upon him said: Indeed, crops grow in the plain and do not grow on the hard rock, likewise wisdom (Hikmah) works in the heart (Qalb) of the humble (Mutawadi') and does not work in the heart (Qalb) of the arrogant (Mutakabbir). Do you not see that whoever raises his head to the ceiling injures it, and whoever lowers it is shaded and sheltered. So this is a parable he struck for the arrogant ones (Mutakabbirun) and how they are deprived of wisdom (Hikmah). And therefore, the Messenger of Allah ï·º mentioned the denial of truth as part of the definition of arrogance (Kibr) and uncovering its reality and said: "Whoever belittles the truth and looks down upon people."
